main_text:
Is Hyperintensionality Real?
2. Is Hyperintensionality Real?

While
 Section 4
 considers some difficulties for specific hyperintensional theories,
here we discuss general objections to the very idea that we need a
theory of language or mind that marks hyperintensional distinctions.
One kind of argument in this ballpark has to do with a general
“Boolean” challenge to formulating a semantics for
hyperintensional expressions in the dominant truth-conditional
framework. This style of argument will be discussed in
 §2.1.

Another kind of argument advanced by defenders of SPWS such as
Stalnaker (1984) and Lewis (1982, 1986), has it that the prima
facie hyperintensionality of knowledge, belief, or content is
misleading, and that SPWS can still do the job once misleading
intuitions have been explained away. This style of argument will be
discussed in
 §2.2.
